title: How to Steam Kale (in a Steamer Basket & the Microwave)

steps.title: Wash 1 bunch of kale.
steps.content: Wash 1 bunch of kale. Rinse the greens with water and slightly dry them to rid them of any dirt. You want your kale to be safe to eat before you start cooking it! You could also use a salad spinner to easily wash the kale. Some people prefer to remove the kale ribs and stalks. If they're particularly large and bothersome, feel free to cut and discard them.

steps.title: Shred your kale finely.
steps.content: Shred your kale finely. Chewing small pieces of kale is better than eating an entire steamed leaf, and they're easier to work with and serve if they're cut up. [1] X Research source You can rip the leaves up by hand or finely cut them with a knife.

steps.title: Fill the steamer with 2 inches (5.1 cm) of water and turn your stove's heat on.
steps.content: Fill the steamer with 2 inches (5.1 cm) of water and turn your stove's heat on. Bring the water to a boil so it begins to bubble. This will get rid of any excess bacteria. [2] X Research source Boiling water is the best way to purify tap water. This makes it safe to drink and cook in. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Mince 1 clove of garlic while your water boils.
steps.content: Mince 1 clove of garlic while your water boils. Place a clove on your cutting board and cut the garlic into small pieces. You could also purchase a jar of minced garlic to save some time.

steps.title: Place the shredded kale and garlic into the steamer basket.
steps.content: Place the shredded kale and garlic into the steamer basket. Using a steamer will prevent your greens from becoming too soggy. Incorporating this into your diet will lower the risk of cancer and cardiovascular disease. [4] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Other leafy greens, such as spinach or collard greens, can also be steamed. [5] X Research source Incorporating steamed greens into your diet lowers the risk of cancer and cardiovascular disease.

steps.title: Reduce the heat so the water simmers and cover with a lid.
steps.content: Reduce the heat so the water simmers and cover with a lid. If the heat is up too high, your kale will cook too quickly and potentially dry out. Simmering also allows your kale to maintain its form. It's gentler than boiling and your kale won't flake apart. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Steam your kale for 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.content: Steam your kale for 5 to 10 minutes. Keep an eye on the greens: you'll know your kale is ready when it begins to look wilted. Remember to toss your kale halfway through so it cooks evenly.

steps.title: Serve your dish.
steps.content: Serve your dish. Your kale is ready to eat! Place it on a plate or in a bowl for others to enjoy. For additional flavor, you can add salt and pepper or drizzle some lemon juice. Steamed kale works great as a side dish or you can add it to something else! Try tossing it with your favorite salad dressing.

steps.title: Place a shredded bunch of kale and a teaspoon of water into a microwave-safe bowl.
steps.content: Place a shredded bunch of kale and a teaspoon of water into a microwave-safe bowl. A lot of water isn’t necessary because kale naturally has water in it. This water is all you’ll need to get it steaming. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the bowl with a paper towel.
steps.content: Cover the bowl with a paper towel. This will keep the heat inside the bowl, making it easier to steam the kale. You can also use microwave-safe plastic wrap. If using this, poke a hole in the top so steam can escape. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Microwave on high for at least 2 minutes.
steps.content: Microwave on high for at least 2 minutes. For every 2 cups of kale, cook for two minutes. Your kale will be ready when it is wilted. [9] X Research source You might need to adjust the cooking time based on your microwave.

steps.title: Drain the water.
steps.content: Drain the water. Pour the bowl into a strainer to remove excess water from the greens. Once most of the liquid is gone, your kale is ready to eat! Put it on a plate or in a serving bowl and serve it next to your main dish. Now you can also add some seasoning if lemon juice if you want more flavor. For a spicy kick, sprinkle some red pepper flakes or some chopped jalapeno peppers.
